static java.lang.String degrees2CompassPoints(double degrees)
          Convert an angle in degrees (such as azimuth) to compass points (N, NNE, NE...etc)
static double EqnEquinox(double Mjd_TT)
          Computation of the equation of the equinoxes Notes: The equation of the equinoxes dpsi*cos(eps) is the right ascension of the mean equinox referred to the true equator and equinox and is equal to the difference between apparent and mean sidereal time.
static double[] EquatorialEquinoxChange(double mjdCurrentEquinox, double[] currentVec, double mjdNewEquinox)
          General function to perform a equinox basis transformation for a vector in Earth equatorial coordinates (e.g., from 2000.0 to 1950.0)

          Converts J2000.0 Coordinates to a new equinox date (such as J2000.0 to Mean of Date, mjdNewEquinox = current date)
static double[] EquatorialEquinoxToJ2K(double mjdCurrentEquinox, double[] currentPos)
          Converts Equatorial Coordinates from any equinox to J2000.0 (such as Mean of Date to J2000.0, mjdCurrentEquinox = current date) NOTE: See J2kCoordinateConversion.java - for possibly better ways to do this

          Coverts a vector in J2000.0 coordinates to TEME (true equator, mean equinox) of Date If you have more than one vector to transform you might want to do this manually to save calculating rotation matrix many times

J2000toTEME

public static org.apache.commons.math3.geometry.euclidean.threed.Vector3D J2000toTEME(double mjd,
                                                                                      double[] vecJ2k)
Coverts a vector in J2000.0 coordinates to TEME (true equator, mean equinox) of Date If you have more than one vector to transform you might want to do this manually to save calculating rotation matrix many times

Parameters:
mjd - modified julian date of the desired coordinate transformation
vecJ2k -
Returns:
teme vector

TEMEtoJ2000

public static double[] TEMEtoJ2000(double mjd,
                                   double[] vecTEME)
Coverts a vector in TEME (true equator, mean equinox) of Date coordinates to J2000.0

Parameters:
mjd - modified julian date of the desired coordinate transformation
vecTEME -
Returns:
J2000.0 vector

public static void j2000toMOD(double mjd,
                              double[] j2kVec1,
                              double[] modVec1,
                              double[] j2kVec2,
                              double[] modVec2)
Converts up to two J2000 vectors to MOD vectors (second vector set can be null)

Parameters:
mjd - modified julian date of the desired coordinate transformation
j2kVec1 - typically position
modVec1 -
j2kVec2 - typically velocity
modVec2 -

j2000toTOD

public static void j2000toTOD(double mjd,
                              double[] j2kVec1,
                              double[] todVec1,
                              double[] j2kVec2,
                              double[] todVec2)
Converts up to two J2000 vectors to TOD vectors (second vector set can be null) delta psi/eps correction to J2000 are set to 0, uses 40 terms of nutation

Parameters:
mjd - modified julian date of the desired coordinate transformation
j2kVec1 - typically position
todVec1 -
j2kVec2 - typically velocity
todVec2 -

EquatorialEquinoxChange

public static double[] EquatorialEquinoxChange(double mjdCurrentEquinox,
                                               double[] currentVec,
                                               double mjdNewEquinox)
General function to perform a equinox basis transformation for a vector in Earth equatorial coordinates (e.g., from 2000.0 to 1950.0)

Parameters:
mjdCurrentEquinox - Current Modified Julian Date Equinox
currentVec - Current vector in Earth equatorial coordinates using mjdCurrentEquinox equinox date (any units of length)
mjdNewEquinox - Modified Julian Date of equinox to transform to
Returns:
vector with equatorial coordinates with equinox of mjdNewEquinox

EquatorialEquinoxFromJ2K

public static double[] EquatorialEquinoxFromJ2K(double mjdNewEquinox,
                                                double[] j2kPos)
Converts J2000.0 Coordinates to a new equinox date (such as J2000.0 to Mean of Date, mjdNewEquinox = current date)

Parameters:
mjdNewEquinox - new equinox date (MJD)
j2kPos - current J2000.0 vector
Returns:
transformed coordintes

EquatorialEquinoxToJ2K

public static double[] EquatorialEquinoxToJ2K(double mjdCurrentEquinox,
                                              double[] currentPos)
Converts Equatorial Coordinates from any equinox to J2000.0 (such as Mean of Date to J2000.0, mjdCurrentEquinox = current date) NOTE: See J2kCoordinateConversion.java - for possibly better ways to do this

Parameters:
mjdCurrentEquinox - current Modified Julian Date of equinox
currentPos - current vector
Returns:
J2000.0 equatorial position vector

PrecMatrix_Equ

public static double[][] PrecMatrix_Equ(double T1,
                                        double T2)
Precession of equatorial coordinates

Parameters:
T1 - Epoch given (current) in Julian centuries since J2000
T2 - Epoch to precess to in Julian centuries since J2000
Returns:
Precession transformation matrix

PrecMatrix_Equ_Mjd

public static double[][] PrecMatrix_Equ_Mjd(double Mjd_1,
                                            double Mjd_2)
Precession of equatorial coordinates, similar to PrecMatrix_Equ, except inputs are Modified Julian Dates

Parameters:
Mjd_1 - Epoch given (Modified Julian Date TT)
MjD_2 - Epoch to precess to (Modified Julian Date TT)
Returns:
Precession transformation matrix

EqnEquinox

public static double EqnEquinox(double Mjd_TT)
Computation of the equation of the equinoxes Notes: The equation of the equinoxes dpsi*cos(eps) is the right ascension of the mean equinox referred to the true equator and equinox and is equal to the difference between apparent and mean sidereal time.

Parameters:
Mjd_TT - Modified Julian Date (Terrestrial Time)
Returns:
Equation of the equinoxes

degrees2CompassPoints

public static java.lang.String degrees2CompassPoints(double degrees)
Convert an angle in degrees (such as azimuth) to compass points (N, NNE, NE...etc)

Parameters:
degrees - (will be converted to [0,360) )
Returns:
compass direction -- if you only want N, NE, E... then check for a length of 3 and drop first char
